Award.AwardTitle: Dynamical Coupling Between Particles and Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research on the motion of nanoparticles in a polymer matrix. The mean square displacement of microscopic particles larger than polymer chains provides information about rheological properties of the surrounding matrix. However, structure and dynamics of complex polymeric materials on sub-molecular length scales as well as microscopic details of polymer-particle interactions are poorly understood. The PI will analyze the motion of nanoparticles smaller than the surrounding polymer chains. Particularly interesting is the coupling of the nanoparticle dynamics to dynamical modes of matrix polymer chains on length scales equal to or smaller than the particle size and to modes of chains adsorbed or grafted to the particle.

A theory of the dynamical coupling between nanoparticles and a polymer matrix will be systematically developed starting from a model of non-sticky particles freely diffusing in polymer networks and gels. Mobility of these trace particles is highly sensitive to the relation between their dimensions and the diameter of the confining tube of the entangled matrix chains. Upon uniaxial and biaxial deformation of polymer networks and gels, the corresponding change of the tube diameter causes anisotropic diffusion of tracer nanoparticles. A method for characterization of the non-affine deformation of the confining tube by measuring the anisotropy of nanoparticle mobility will be developed and tested by computer simulations. The developed models will also enable quantitative analysis of translational and rotational diffusion of non-spherical nanoparticles, such as nanorods with diameter smaller than the mesh size of polymer gels and length longer than this mesh size.

The model will be extended to the case of sticky nanoparticles that exhibit hindered diffusion through polymeric liquids or solids due to chains attached to these particles. The time dependence of the mean square displacement of the sticky particles will reflect both dynamics of attached chains as well as of the surrounding polymer matrix. The proposed theory will allow separation of both contributions and determination of the structure and dynamics of the polymer layer adsorbed on nanoparticles. This theory will be modified to treat the finite lifetime of the bonds between particles and adsorbed polymers and the lifetime of labile bonds in reversible networks.

The theory of mobility of sticky particles will be extended to treat heterogeneous medium with a distribution of local sticky regions using an activated hopping model. A general solution of this model will be obtained to allow the derivation of the distribution of attraction strengths of different sticky regions from the analysis of particle trajectories.

This project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral fellows in analytical and numerical techniques for soft materials. Some of the results of this research will be used in the development of new problem sets and supplementary materials for the PIs textbook "Polymer Physics." The project will also be used as a tool for engage the interest of high school students in modern scientific methods by engaging them in active research.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research to study nanoparticles, particles some 100,000 times smaller than the diameter of a human hair, moving within a material made up of a tangle of long chain-like molecules called polymers. Understanding the mechanisms by which the nanoparticles move provides useful information about the properties of materials made of polymers. The PI will develop a theory that can handle nanoparticles of different sized and shape, as well as kind, including nanoparticles with smooth surfaces and nanoparticles that have polymers attached to them which tend to make them "sticky" as they interact with the polymers that make up the material. This research will has impact on technological applications, such as optimizing composite materials and designing nanoparticles for drug delivery applications.

This project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral fellows in analytical and numerical techniques for soft materials. Some of the results of this research will be used in the development of new problem sets and supplementary materials for the PI's textbook "Polymer Physics." The project will also be used as a tool for engage the interest of high school students in modern scientific methods by engaging them in active research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamical coupling between nanoparticles and a polymer matrix Nanoparticle-polymer coupling is important for the fabrication and processing of polymer nanoparticle (NP) composites, which often exhibit improved mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties with respect to pure polymeric materials. Using the combination of scaling analysis and molecular simulations, we have systematically studied NP-polymer coupling.

Our research has demonstrated important features of NP-polymer coupling. For NPs in entangled linear polymers, we show that the motion of NPs is strongly suppressed as NP size exceeds the mesh size a of the entanglement network. This suppression is related to the confinement of NPs by the entanglement network. NPs with sizes moderately larger than the entanglement mesh size a are not completely confined. We have proposed a hopping diffusion mechanism to describe the mobility of these NPs.

NP-polymer coupling is affected by the architectures of the polymers. We have compared the motion of NPs in entangled melts of linear polymers and non-concatenated ring polymers. The motion of large NPs in ring polymers is not as strongly suppressed as that in linear polymers. This comparison provides a paradigm for the effects of polymer architectures on NP-polymer coupling.

On the basis of the studies of NPs in polymer melts, we have explored the extension of micro-rheology to nano-rheology. Micro-rheology measures the bulk viscoelasticity of a medium through tracking the motion of embedded particles. Nano-rheology is based on tracking of nanoparticles whose sizes are smaller than or comparable to the intrinsic structural length scales of the medium, and thus only explores the local viscoelasticity. We obtained the first set of nanorheological data by converting the NP mean-squared displacement to an effective stress relaxation modulus. This research will guide nano-rheological experiments.

Another focus of our research is the coupling between nanoparticles and sticky environment. Such a coupling occurs in industrial tires as well as in human mucus gels. As a prototype model of sticky nanoparticle motion, we have developed a scaling theory for the mobility of polymer-tethered NPs. The theory demonstrates that their motion in a polymer matrix is controlled by the competition between the dynamics of the bare NP and the dynamics of tethered polymers. This study provides a theoretical guidance for controlling the motion of NPs by manipulating tethered polymers.

 

Broader Impacts

Soft Matter is a relatively new, but rapidly growing area of science and engineering grounded in the mature field of polymer science, but extending well beyond its boundaries to adjacent fields, such as colloids and liquid crystals as well as to physical biology and medicine. The activities in this field are still poorly interconnected and take place under the auspices of scientific societies related to different disciplines (APS, ACS, MRS, AIChE, Biophysical, Rheology, etc.).

PI has organized and is leading a Working Group of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics, the goal of which is to connect activities in soft matter between its different sub-disciplines and different geographic regions (http://iupap.org/working-groups/wg15-soft-matter/). The main objectives of this Working Group are:

1.     To organize an International Conference “Soft Matter Around the World” which rotates every 3 years to each geographic region (Europe-Africa, the Americas, and Asia-Pacific).

2.     To coordinate soft-matter-related regional, national & local conferences, meetings & workshops.

3.     To coordinate soft matter education, such as summer/winter schools and short courses and help organize them.

4.     To promote soft matter research through information exchange, publicity, prizes, publications, etc.

5.     To strengthen the connections between academic and industrial soft matter research and development through outreach events, short courses, etc.

In addition PI facilitated formation of the new Soft Matter Topical Group of American Physical Society and acted as a Chair of Editorial Board of “Soft Matter” Royal Society of Chemistry Journal. He is also the Leader of US Unit of Soft Matter International Research and Education Center, GI-CORE Global Institution for Collaborative Research and Education (https://gi-core.oia.hokudai.ac.jp/gss/members-2/us-unit/). PI serves on International Advisory Boards of Marie Curie Network SUPOLEN and of SOFI CDT EPSRC Center for Doctoral Training in Soft Matter and Functional Interfaces, UK. He was a co-organizer of the Fifth International Conference on Self-Healing Materials held in Durham, North Carolina; of the theory session at Pacific Polymer Conference held at Kauai, HI, and of the Cyclic Polymer Workshops held on Crete, Greece.

PI organized and taught in a number of international summer schools including Summer School in Hokkaido, Japan (2017); summer school on Physics and Mechanics of Soft Complex Materials in Cargese, France (2016); summer school on Theory and Simulations of Polyelectrolytes in Moscow, Russia (2016); DPOLY Short Course on Nanocomposites at 2016 APS March Meeting; a course on polyelectrolytes at FORTH, Heraklion, Greece (2015); SUPOLEN summer school on Capri, Italy (2015); Enrico Fermi International School of Physics, Varena, Italy (2015); and IRTG 1524 and MRSEC summer school, Beverly, MA (2014).
